citation.article-title: Glaciecola psychrophila sp. nov., a novel psychrophilic bacterium isolated from the Arctic.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Glaciecola psychrophila sp. nov.
Glaciecola psychrophila (psy.chro′phi.la. Gr. adj. psychros cold; Gr. adj. philus loving; N.L. fem. adj. psychrophila cold loving).
Cells are Gram-negative, psychrophilic, motile rods, 0.5–0.8 μm by 1.2–4.5 μm in size.
Colonies are non-pigmented, convex, circular and smooth with entire edges.
Grows aerobically and produces catalase and cytochrome oxidase.
Growth occurs at 4–15 °C and pH 5.0–10.0, with optimum growth at 12 °C and at approximately pH 6.0–9.0.
Growth occurs in the presence of 1–6 % (w/v) NaCl and no growth occurs in the absence of NaCl.
Indole production and Voges–Proskauer reaction are negative.
Negative results for the reduction of nitrate and production of hydrogen sulfide.

Negative in tests for arginine dihydrolase, lysine decarboxylase, ornithine decarboxylase, urease, gelatinase, caseinase, agarase, chitinase, lecithinase, esterase (C4), esterase lipase (C8), acid phosphatase, β-glucuronidase, β-glucosidase, α-glucosidase, N-acetyl-β-glucosaminidase, α-mannosidase and α-fucosidase.
Weak enzymic activity is observed for trypsin, lipase (C14) and cystine arylamidase.
Tests for naphthol-AS-BI-phosphohydrolase, α-chymotrypsin, amylase, alkaline phosphatase, leucine arylamidase, valine arylamidase and β-galactosidase are positive.
The following substrates are utilized as sole carbon sources: sucrose, maltose, lactose, galactose, gluconate and pyruvate.
Acid is weakly produced from maltose and galactose.

The following substrates are not utilized as sole carbon sources: glucose, d-mannose, mannitol, fructose, cellobiose, l-arabinose, xylose, l-rhamnose, d-melibiose, raffinose, d-sorbitol, sorbinose, glycerol, melezitose, ribose, galactitol, inositol, erythritol, salicin, inulin, valine, glycine, cysteine, arginine, histidine, lysine, methionine, N-acetylglucosamine, acetate, fumarate, hippurate, lactate, malate, citrate, succinate, tartrate, alginate, capric acid, adipic acid, phenylacetic acid and uric acid.
The predominant cellular fatty acids are C16 : 1ω7c (38.31 %), C16 : 0 (13.59 %), C12 : 1 3-OH (6.47 %), C18 : 1ω7c (6.23 %), C14 : 0 (5.48 %) and C17 : 1ω8c (2.73 %).
The G+C content of the DNA is 42.9 mol%.
The type strain, 170T (=CGMCC 1.6130T=JCM 13954T), was collected from high latitude Arctic locations (77° 30′ N to approximately 81° 12′ N), including the Canadian Basin and Greenland Sea.
